page.title: 08BOWNESS-ON-SOLWAY.ECOLOGY 2.
page.content: The estuary contains Salmon, Mullet, Flounders, Trout, Eels, all fished in season. Large flocks of sea-birds also feed off the numerous molluscs and bivalves. Many birdwatchers come to see them at migration times. There is evidence of a submerged forest on very low tides, east of Bowness village. Glacial debris along southern estuary shore includes granite carried south from Scotland. Scours: hummocks of boulder clay laid East-to-West in direction of glacial flow. Pockets of quicksand are found where creeks or springs enter. (A horse sank as recently as l980). Tides average 20-30ft. The bore (up to three feet high) may be seen when conditions are right. The tide runs very quickly, especially under a westerly gale. .Bowness Moss has been designated an area of Special Scientific Interest.
